There is considerable progress made towards the attainment of this outcome The installation of the early warning infrastructure is underway as ten automated weather stations have been procured and installed in six out of seven districts 86 coverage of the project area which constitutes at least 9 of national coverage Data from the AWS is being generated on an hourly basis Hydrological equipment has been procured but not yet installed Once installed it is expected that it will contribute to at least 6 of national coverage Modest progress has been registered that can be measured based on the indicators During the reporting period in question the focus was on preparatory activities

activity-description.narrative: Climate Proofing Local Development Gains in Urban and Rural areas of Machinga and Mangochi Districts in Malawi. The project intends to address impact of ecosystems degradation and increasing resilience of development gains. The lessons are to be integrated into key decision-making processes at the

comment.narrative: 1. Training of resource user groups and Village Natural Resource Management Committees (VNRMCs) in ecosystem-based CC adaptation completed in districts. 2. District authorities trained in Community-based Resilience Analysis (CoBRA) and integration of climate change adaptation into district development plans. 3. Comprehensive baseline assessment conducted to identify multi-hazard and risk hotspots to inform adaptation interventions (e.g., flood control) 4. Forest user groups formulated in watershed catchment areas, tree nurseries and planting in basin, and user by-laws prepared and enforced. 5. Irrigation systems rehabilitated in districts, training of farmers in climate-smart fisheries, fish ponds rehabilitating and adaptation measures in place.

1. Adoption rate for ecosystem-based climate change adaptation undetermined during reporting period. 2. Policy integration of climate change adaptation into district plans undetermined during reporting period. 3. Procurement of goods and services underway for installation of physical infrastructure to regulate water supply and flood control (e.g., water harvesting technology, rehabilitation of irrigation infrastructure) 4. % increase (h) of catchment areas under protection undetermined during reporting period. 5. % of pop. adopting climate resilient agriculture undetermined during reporting period.

1. six comprehensive community based adaptation plans integrating traditional and technical knowledge 2.Community awareness and involvement in monitoring vulnerability to climate change 3.Extension packages for fishery sector updated with climate change information and current CC management tools and techniques 4. Physical infrastructure constructed to demonstrate and regulate water supply and flood control in the targeted hotspot catchment area under protection;100 check dams, nullahs, and other structures 5. Suppport Community Based institutional strengthening through revival and registration of Village Forest Areas and revival of Civil Protection Committees.

1. Six (6) community based adaptation plans were developed for 6 target hotspot. 2. Community Based Resilience Assessment (CoBRA) tool was carried out in 6 hotspots in highly participatory approach that enabled community members to self define resilience characteristics. Thirsty (30) plus resilience building blocks were identified and integrated in Community Based Adaptation (CBA) action plans. 3.Production of key extension mannual in Climate Smart Agriculture, Climate Smart Fishiries Mannual and water management mannual. 4.Disaster contingency plan for Machinga District has been updated. Two district development plans for Machinga and Mangochi districts are being updated with climate change resilience indicators. 5.Over 1,000 check dams, swalley, nullas and infiltration pits were constructed as part of watershed management and soil conservation activities. Supported 75 households with demonstration and installation of above the ground water harvesting technologies for roof top rain water harvesting system. 6.Three (3) Village Natural Resource Management Committes managing 3 village forest areas have been registered in Mwima under Nyambi,Namosi under Mlomba and Makoka under Chikweo. Civil Protection Committees have been revamped and recruited over 75 volunteers to support disaster risk management activities.

1. 20% of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender) 2. Six (6) district planning instruments DDPs, DESOER, DIIAT updated with climate change adaptation information 3. Two (2) dams constructed, 6 IAA ponds constructed, 60 HHs participating in roof-top rain water harvesting, 10 community structures supported with skills in disaster management; 4 Village Forest Areas registered; 4. three (3) Kilometres of river and lake shore under protection; 40 ha of forest under improved management; 200hh and 3 public institutions using renewable energy technologies. 5. 200 Households with diversified income sources; 1000ha of land under CSA; 50MT cereal seed produced; 60ha area of land under climate smart small holder irrigation; 5% reduction in post-harvest losses to participating households; 2 CSA centres established.

comment.narrative: 1. Approach to coordination of district-level adaptation activities approved by District Councils in Ntcheu, Zomba, Nkhata Bay. 2. Workplans, M&E and reporting templates, procurement systems, and budget requirements understood by all district-level stakeholders. 3. Local leaders and district groups trained in formulation and management of resource user groups (e.g., fisheries, water/irrigation, forest woodlots).

1. convened coordination meeting of district authorities and UN agencies (e.g., WFP and FAO) to agree on division of labour and joint approach to ensure complementarity of activities (Zomba). Ntcheu and Nkhata Bay planned for 2017. 2. Training of district authorities in UNDP due diligence systems conducted in Zomba and Ntcheu. 3. Training of sector authorities, local leaders, and resource user groups in co-management of natural resources. 4.Compiled raw footage and case studies, a video documentary on the project best practices produced 6.Training Needs Assessment for staff on climate change adaptation and Gender Mainstreaming was conducted in the 3 districts and reports produced which informed development of a capacity development training on climate change and gender mainstreaming.

1. 3Climate change adaptation and Incentive Plans developed and implemented -At least 3 DDPs and 3 Village Action Plans 2. 60 District and Sub-District officers in each of the 3 Districts (180 in total) trained on adaptation technical themes and are able to mainstream CCA in district development plans 3.Adaptation investment priorities for Malawi are identified- Malawi Climate Change Fund designed

1.Community Based Resilience Analysis (CoBRA) assessments resulted in development of the 3 district level Community Based Adaptation Action Plans. 2. Supported the mainstreaming of climate change resilience and adaptation in the design of Malawi Growth and Development Strategy (MGDS) III (2018 - 2023). 3. CoBRA findings and vulnerability assessments are being used to update and integrate Climate Change Adaptation strategiesof District Development Plans (DDPs) - 2017 - 2022. 30 national level Government staff (21 men and 9 women) and 55 district staff (19 women and 36 men) benefited from the capacity building initiatives on CCA integration. Community Based Resilience Analysis training of trainers provided to 45 district sectoral staff in 3 districts to be the champions of resilience/adaptation capacity building, district planning and budgeting. 4. Various diversified livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable people in target areas. A total of, 800 households were trained in various adaptation intervention of their choice; (55% women, 40% men and 5% youths and other vulnerable groups). 8 irrigation schemes established, 15 fish ponds constructed and stocked. 17 beekeeping groups established. 1,400 households with various project activities reached so far-1,500 hectares planted with bananas. 1,250 hectares of land planted with different citrus fruits. 12000 trees planted 5. The project supported climate change adaptation costing work by supporting a discourse on the establishment of the National Climate Change Fund for Malawi. A Task-force formed, stakeholder workshop conducted and a road map for the establishment of the fund developed.

1. At least 2200 HH to be trained in CCA; At least 15 stakeholder partner coordination, and learning platform meetings; 6 stakeholder partner coordination meetings to scale up application of CCA in government policies and programmes. 1 annual CCA success story published on MNREM website - 2 newsletters, 3 newspaper articles, 2 media tours & 2 visits. 3 case studies - 1 video documentaries - successful hosting of CBA12 2. one *(1) consolidated, nationally sanctioned manual on EBA/CCA produced; 180 staff (60 staff/district). 2. Percentage of district and Sub-district officers trained on adaptation technical themes and are able to mainstream in district development plans 3. three (3) sector strategies (Water resource, Forestry and Agriculture) integrate CCA costing 4 . 5 sets of by-laws, and 3 district strategies revised 5. Three (3) expenditure reviews (1 review in each district); 30 national and district staff trained in Climate Adaptation Expenditure Review methodology (10 per district); 90 stakeholders exposed to CPEIR methodology 6. Livelihoods activities targeting 600 households - 2 integrated water supply systems - 3 irrigation schemes (10 hectares each) - 6 fish ponds (20 by 20 m) - 15 boreholes (Ntcheu, Zomba & Nkhatabay) -8000 grafted fruit trees -10,000 bamboos - 9 community enterprise development trainings - 1 value chain mapping study - mapping of community contributions to climate resilient infrastructure Adaptation investment priorities for Malawi are identified and malawi Climate Change Fund designed
